private java.lang.String name
The name of the class (not fully qualified, just the name).

parent

private JavaClass parent
The parent class. This is going to be something from "extends" or java.lang.Object.

methods

private java.util.HashMap<java.lang.String,java.util.ArrayList<JavaMethod>> methods
List of all virtual methods in this class (v is for virtual). Method name -> Method object

classMethods

private java.util.HashMap<java.lang.String,java.util.ArrayList<JavaMethod>> classMethods
The list of all the methods that are defined in this class.

vtable

private java.util.ArrayList<JavaMethod> vtable
The VTable list of methods (in the order they need to appear). This is used for nothing but maintaining the order of the VTable.

fieldTable

private java.util.ArrayList<JavaField> fieldTable
Kinda like the vTable, but for fields -- they are all in the order that they are inherited in.

isSetup

private boolean isSetup
A flag that indicates if we have loaded our data layout and methods completely. It stops circular resolution that kills child loading.

isPrinted

private boolean isPrinted
A flag that indicates if we have printed yet. This stops classes from printing before their data layouts have been setup.

childClasses

private java.util.ArrayList<JavaClass> childClasses
A list of the children that need to be alerted when our data layout has been setup.

Overrides:
onNodeSetup in class ActivatableVisitor

process

protected void process()
Only to be used upon activation. Does everything we need to get this class ready for translation. The first phase of class activation.

Specified by:
process in class ActivatableVisitor

alertParentSetup

private void alertParentSetup()
The second phase of the class activation. This is only called when the parent has been setup and we can access the parent's data layout.

alertPrint

private void alertPrint()
We have an alert print method so that, once our parent has finished all his setup. Because once a file is activate it triggers activation of all the children classes, we can be assured that all children will print once their parents have resolved all their dependencies and printed. This ensures that things print out in the right order and that circular dependencies don't cause things to break.

checkParentReady

private void checkParentReady(JavaClass child)
Checks if the data layout for this class has been setup. If it has not been, then it adds the class that checked to see if it is setup to the list of "children" classes of this guy, and when the parent has been setup, the child classes will be alerted so that they can setup their data.

checkParentPrinted

private void checkParentPrinted(JavaClass child)
We can only print if our parent is printed and setup. We do this so that circular dependencies don't cause errors.

Determines if we are a subclass of another class.

getMethod

public JavaMethod getMethod(JavaMethod m)
Replaces the older version of getMethod() to take into account overaloding: it will find the method that has the signature closest to the one provided.

Returns:
The method that is the closest match to the requested method signature. Null if no method was found (but since the Java is assumed to compile, this should be considered a fatal internal error.

getMethod

public JavaMethod getMethod(java.lang.String name,
                            JavaMethodSignature sig,
                            java.util.HashMap<java.lang.String,java.util.ArrayList<JavaMethod>> searchMethods)
Replaces the older version of getMethod() to take into account overaloding: it will find the method that has the signature closest to the one provided.

Parameters:
name - The name of the method.
sig - The method signature.
searchMethods - Which set of methods should be searched for the requested method.
Returns:
The method that is the closest match to the requested method signature. Null if no method was found (but since the Java is assumed to compile, this should be considered a fatal internal error.

setParent

private void setParent(java.lang.String parent)
Setup our parent. Can only be run once, then everything is permanent.

getParent

public JavaClass getParent()

setupDataLayout

private void setupDataLayout()
Go through all the parents and get their virtual methods, then just add them. To do this, we test if we first have a parent (java.lang.Object doesn't); if we have a parent, grab his virtual methods, see if we override them, if we don't, then add them, otherwise, ignore. Then, add all of the fields that our parent has (at face value), then go through and add all of our fields, and we use the names of our parent fields to mangle the names of our local fields.

visitExtension

public void visitExtension(xtc.tree.GNode n)
Handles resolving dependencies for inheritance. When it sees an extension, it throws the name to its parent file's import manager in order to resolve the name and activate the class so that it can extend it properly.

visitMethodDeclaration

public void visitMethodDeclaration(xtc.tree.GNode n)
Take in a method. Adds the method to our method table.
